content.webTitle: Warrington Wolves take Jordan Cox out of comfort zone in Super League

fields.headline: Warrington Wolves take Jordan Cox out of comfort zone in Super League
fields.bodyText: Jordan Cox could be forgiven for sitting down and trying to catch his breath given how much of a whirlwind have been the past few months of his life. Late last year he was told by his hometown club Hull Kingston Rovers that he was not needed for 2016, a decision which left the 23-year-old fearing a step down into the Championship and a move away from Super League was his only option. Yet on Sunday Cox is preparing to take on the club he had been at since the age of 12 with Warrington, after a service station meeting with the Wolves coach, Tony Smith, gave his career the impetus it so desperately needed. “It’s done me the world of good to get out of Hull, because I did get comfortable there,” Cox admits. “I had my feet under the table, but coming here has been an absolute revelation.” With Cox’s departure from the Robins only confirmed late into pre-season, the prop feared that most clubs would have no room for him. He even came close to working for Smith’s brother, Brian. “On the first day of pre-season I was informed that [the Hull KR coach] Chris Chester didn’t see me in his plans,” Cox recalls. “I rang my agent and said that I needed another club because they didn’t want me there. He said that most of them were set for 2016 and I might have to drop down a division for a season. “However, within two hours Brian Smith wanted to meet me and sign me for Wakefield, but while I was driving back from there, Tony wanted to meet up too. We met at a service station and as soon as I met him, I knew there was nowhere else I was going to sign. I rang Brian and said thanks for the interest, but Warrington was just too good to turn down.” Now living on the other side of the country in Warrington – “that was frightening at first, because my mum did everything for me” – Cox is aiming to show his former employers what they missed out on on Sunday by helping the Wolves to a second straight victory at the start of the new season. “When I signed and saw the fixtures, I told Tony I’d make the team for the Hull KR game,” Cox says. “I’ll probably get belted and they’ll come after me, but I’ll just treat it as another game. I’ve nothing against Hull KR – that’s sport – but the timing has been impeccable for me. Leaving there has been a blessing in disguise for my career.” Rob Burrow will captain Leeds Rhinos in the absence of their regular captain Danny McGuire as they face Widnes Vikings in their final match before Sunday’s World Club Challenge against North Queensland. The hooker Beau Falloon, who missed last week’s defeat to Warrington, is still sidelined with a foot injury. The final fixture features Castleford against Wakefield in a West Yorkshire derby, with the Tigers having to deal with the loss of their captain, Michael Shenton, who suffered a long-term knee injury during the draw at Hull KR last weekend.
